content:
If you mean can you use a web-mail address like GMail, HotMail, Outlook &c in Thunderbird then yes.

Thunderbird can't give you a web-mail address, or any other type, as it's an e-mail client not a provider.
creator: ThePillenwerfer

content:
If you mean is there @thunderbird.net email addresses that the general public can get then no. There is already a huge number of email providers out there already.

The Thunderbird email client is is operated by the Mozilla Foundation's subsidiary MZLA Technologies Corporation.

Mozilla does manually provide @mozilla.org/.com email addresses to people working for Mozilla in a capacity that warrants having one. If they leave Mozilla then they have to give it up.
creator: James

content:
You need to check your settings as things are changing.

Press Alt-e and choose 'Account Settings' from the drop-down menu that appears, then click 'Server Settings' under the HotMail account and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: outlook.office365.com  Port: 993  User Name: <your e-mail address>  Connection security:  SSL/TLS  Authentication method: OAuth2

Now click 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' in the left hand column. Double click the 'Outlook.com (Microsoft)' entry and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: smtp.office365.com  Port: 587  Connection security: STARTTLS  Authentication method:  OAuth2  User Name: <your e-mail address>
creator: ThePillenwerfer

content:
This is what you need to do.

Press Alt-e and choose 'Account Settings' from the drop-down menu that appears, then click 'Server Settings' under the account and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: outlook.office365.com  Port: 993  User Name: <your e-mail address>  Connection security:  SSL/TLS  Authentication method: OAuth2

Now click 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' in the left hand column. Double click the 'Outlook.com (Microsoft)' entry and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: smtp.office365.com  Port: 587  Connection security: STARTTLS  Authentication method:  OAuth2  User Name: <your e-mail address>
creator: ThePillenwerfer

content: I found a solution: 1. Find the new Thunderbird folder: 1a. From the 'hamburger' menu, select Help > Troubleshooting information. 1b. Under "Application basics" scroll down to "Profiles" and click the link to "about:profiles" 1c Scroll down to "Root Directory" and click the link to "Open Directory." 2. Create a new directory with an extension of ".default" (I called mine "Leon.default") 3. Copy the "profiles.ini" to a different directory (e.g. your own "Documents" directory) so that you can edit it. 4. Use an editor such as LibreOffice Writer to edit "profiles.ini" 5. change the "Path" from "xxxx.default" (where "xxxx" can be a string of numbers and letters) to the name of the new directory that you created (e.g. my new directory was "Leon.default") 6. Save the new "profiles.ini" file. 7. Copy or move the new "profiles.ini" file so that it over-writes the "profiles.ini" file in the new Thunderbird folder. 8. Find your old Thunderbird folder (Mine was in a hidden directory called ".thunderbird"). 9. Find the most recent subdirectory there that has a ".default" extension. It will have a name like "51ymuit0.default." 10. Open that subdirectory 11. Move the contents of that subdirectory into the new subdirectory that you created in step 2 (Mine was called "Leon.default). 12. Start Thunderbird. If everything works, your old emails and settings will be restored.
creator: leon.arundell

content:
OAuth2 should be below NTLM so make sure you're scrolling right down.

Have you set the other things correctly, Server Name to smtp.office365.com, Port 587, Connection security STARTTLS?

Finally are you using an at least fairly recent version of Thunderbird as old ones can't do it.

Per the MS announcement, some versions of Outlook will not be able to support the Oauth2 authentication, but the announcement does not state that no version of Outlook is supported. The implication is that newer versions work okay. Here is the MS message: 

https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/modern-authentication-methods-now-needed-to-continue-syncing-outlook-email-in-non-microsoft-email-apps-c5d65390-9676-4763-b41f-d7986499a90d

content: I was attempting to answer question 4, but apparently missed. My inference is that it stops working on September 16, but that an updated version is available. It's been years since I used Outlook, so can't advise on any versions. Regarding question 2, I believe you can import contact info if in csv or ldif format. On question 3, there are two layouts for the addressbook. That can be set by clicking the icon to the right of the search box on the addressbook pane, ticking (or unticking) table view. On question 1, I defer to others. If you need to convert quickly, I believe there are a few proprietary products to convert PST to mbox, but I have no experience with them. I wish you well in this.
creator: davidsk

content: First, this is an English language forum. We're generally fine to use web translate for short paragraphs, but if you want to post something this long, please translate first. Second, I will infer that this relates to the MS announcement for Oauth2. So, assuming I am correct, the changes needed are to use different server names: outlook.office365.com and SSL/TLS and 993 and Oauth2 for incoming, and smtp.office365.com and STARTTLS and 587 and Oauth2 for output.
creator: davidsk

content: Yes, they are stored within the accounts in either the imapmail or mail folders, and the name is msgfilterrules.dat . These are simple text files and can be viewed with notepad or similar text editor.
creator: davidsk
